newsitem.title: USA: Stocks pulled down by sell-off in technology sector.
newsitem.headline: Stocks pulled down by sell-off in technology sector.

text.p: Stocks skidded Tuesday amid a sell-off in shares of recently high-flying technology companies as Digital Equipment Corp. reported a bigger-than-expected loss.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed 29.07 points lower, a loss of 0.48 percent, at 6,061.80.
The technology-laden Nasdaq Composite index plunged 16.41 points, or 1.33 percent, to 1,220.00.
In the broader market, declining issues led advances 1,513 to 909 on active volume of 410 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
"The market has run out of steam," said Hildegard Zagorski, an analyst at Prudential Securities.
"Yesterday was the tip-off when IBM had good earnings and the stock rocketed up and then fell apart. Then we had Microsoft. Not helping today was Digital with its big loss," she said.
Digital disappointed Wall Street with a loss of $66 million in its fiscal first quarter. Microsoft Corp.'s earnings of $614 million, while solid, were not as high as expected.
"A lot of technology earnings have met expectations and in some cases were better than expected," said Peter Cardillo, director of research of Westfalia Investments.
"But that's already in the price. Profit-taking will continue for the next week or so right into the U.S. elections," he said.
Digital stock slumped 5-3/8 to 29 on the NYSE, and Microsoft lost 1-1/2 to 132-1/2 on Nasdaq.
"A lot of damage was done in Nasdaq today," said Ralph Bloch, chief technical analyst at Raymond James.
He noted, however, that the market was ripe for a correction after a fast-paced rebound from the correction during the May-July period.
"The market has used up an incredible amount of firepower from the mid-July low," Bloch said.
The Nasdaq index has jumped 15.8 percent since bottoming in July, and the Dow index is up 13 percent.
Managed care companies were another hard-hit sector, with industry analysts citing investor nervousness about third quarter earnings.
Among the big losers, Oxford Health fell 3-1/8 to 41-1/4, United Health shed 1-3/4 to 36-3/4, PacifiCare Health Systems lost 2-15/16 to 68-5/16 and FHP International fell 1/2 to 35-1/4.

HMO-related companies also were hurt, with Amisys Managed plunging 5, or 20 percent, to 30. Medaphis tumbled 6-3/8 to 10-3/8, or 38 percent, after reporting a much wider than expected third quarter loss.
Among technology stocks, International Business Machines Corp. shed 3 to 127, Intel was off 2-1/4 to 105-1/2, Sun Microsystems lost 1-3/16 to 59-1/8, while Motorola was unchanged at 48-1/4.
Compuware surged 5 to 52-1/4 on stronger earnings.

General Motors rose 3/4 to 54-5/8. The Canadian Auto Workers union reached an agreement with General Motors Corp. to end a crippling 19-day strike by 26,000 workers across Canada that also idled 20,000 in the United States and Mexico.
Salomon Inc. lost 3-1/4 to 45-3/8 after reporting a drop in third-quarter earnings.
Several pharmaceutical firms reported results that were either in line with or above Wall Street expectations, driven by strong demand for new drugs.
Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. rose 2-3/4 to 106-7/8, and Eli Lilly gained 1/2 to 69-1/4. Warner-Lambert lost 7/8 at 65-1/4, and American Home Products slipped 1/2 to 65-7/8.
Ontrack Data International, a data recovery company, rose 2-1/2 to 14-1/2 in its first day of trading.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 3.28 points to 706.57. The American Stock Exchange index was off 3.58 to 573.29.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 1.70 to 376.22. The average share was down 19 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 6,880.260 down 47.162 or 0.68 percent.
